data.title: Video Game Console Media
data.meta_description: All forms of media for home and handheld video game consoles, including ROM cartridges, floppy and optical discs and memory cards. See also the ROM Cartridges…
data.text:
All forms of media for home and handheld video game consoles, including ROM cartridges, floppy and optical discs and memory cards.

See also the ROM Cartridges and Cards page for home computers, arcade machines and educational consoles.

Contents

First Generation (1972 – early 1980s)

Second Generation (1976 – 1992)

Third Generation (1983 – 2003)

Fourth Generation (1987 – 2004)

Fifth Generation (1993 – 2006)

Sixth Generation (1998 – 2013)

Seventh Generation (2005 – 2017)

Eighth Generation (2012 – )

Ninth Generation (2020- )

First Generation (1972 – early 1980)

Magnavox launches the first-generation of home video game consoles with the Odyssey. Most consoles of this generation were simple ‘pong’-style consoles that played simple built-in games, but the Odyssey used removable printed circuit boards to select the chosen game.​

Magnavox Odyssey (1972 – 1975)

The PC-50x family of consoles introduced cartridges, but these were not ROM cartridges and each cartridge contained a dedicated General Instrument chip.

General Instrument PC-50x cartridge (1977 – early 1980s)

Second Generation (1976 – 1992)

The Fairchild Channel F is the first video game console to use interchangeable ROM cartridges, and begins the second-generation (sometime called the early 8-bit era) of video game consoles.

Fairchild Channel F / Channel F System II (1976 – 1984)

Most manufacturers of first-generation pong-style video game consoles leave the market due to the first video game crash (1977)

Coleco Telstar Arcade (1977 – 1978) RCA Studio II (1977 – 1978)

The Atari Video Computer System (VCS) is launched, becoming the 2600 in late 1982. It becomes the second-generation’s most popular video game console (1977)

Atari VCS / 2600 (1977 – 1992) Bally Astrocade (1977 – 1984) Interton VC 4000 (1978 – 1983) Philips Videopac / Magnavox Odyssey² (1978 – 1984) Voltmace / Videomaster Database Games-Computer (1978 – early 1980s) Rowtron / Teleng T.C.S (1979 – early 1980s) Prinztronic Tournament VC6000 (1979 – early 1980s) Acetronic MPU-1000 (1979 – 1981) Milton Bradley Microvision (1979 – 1981) Mattel IntelliVision / IntelliVision II (1979 – 1990) Epoch Cassette Vision (1981 – 1984) Emerson Arcadia 2001 (1982 – 1984) ColecoVision (1982 – 1984) Atari 5200 SuperSystem (1982 – 1984)

Due to market saturation and price drops of home computers, the second video game crash occurs (1983)

GCE / Milton Bradley Vectrex (1983 – 1984)

Third Generation (1983 – 2003)

The third-generation (sometime called the 8-bit era) of video game consoles begins with the Nintendo Famicom and Sega SG-1000 in Japan.

Nintendo Famicom (1983 – 2003) Sega SG-1000 / SC-3000 (1983 – 1985)

Casio PV-1000 (1983 – 1984)

Epoch Super Cassette Vision (1984 – late 1980s)

Epoch Super Lady Cassette Vision (1985)

The Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) (a redesigned version of the Nintendo Famicom) is launched in the US and helps revive the video game console industry (1985)

Nintendo Entertainment System (1985 -1995) BBC Bridge Companion (1985 – mid 1980s) Sega My Card (1985 – 1987) Sega Mark III (1985 – 1987) Atari 7800 ProSystem (1986 – 1992) Sega Master System (1986 – 1996) Nintendo Famicom Disk System (1986 – early 1990s) Worlds of Wonder Action Max Game Video (1987 – 1988) Sega Card (1987 – 1989) Commodore 64 Games System (1990 – 1991) Amstrad GX4000 (1990 – 1991)

Fourth Generation (1987 – 2004)

The fourth-generation (also known as the 16-bit era) of video game consoles begins with the launch in Japan of the NEC PC Engine.

NEC PC Engine / TurboGrafx-16 HuCard (1987 – 1994) Sega Mega Drive / Genesis (1988 – 1998)

The NEC PC Engine becomes the first video game console to use CD-ROM as a storage system, through the use of the CD-ROM² System add-on (1988)

NEC PC Engine / TurboGrafx-16 CD-ROM² (1988 – 1994) Atari Lynx (1989 – 1995) Nintendo Game Boy (1989 – 1999) Bit Corporation Gamate (1990 – 1995) Nintendo Super Famicom / Super Nintendo Entertainment System (1990 – 2003) SNK Neo Geo AES (1990 – 2004) SNK Neo Geo AES memory card (1990 – 2004) Commodore CDTV (1991 – 1993) CD-i (Compact Disc Interactive) (1991 – 1998)

Sega Mega-CD (1991 – 1996)

Sega Game Gear (1991 – 1997) Super Nintendo Entertainment System (North American version) (1991 – 1999)

Tandy / Memorex VIS CD-ROM (1992 – 1994)

SNK Neo Geo CD / CDZ (1994 – 1999)

Fifth Generation (1993 – 2006)

The fifth-generation (also known as the 32-bit era, the 64-bit era and the 3D era) of video game consoles begins, and marks a shift from cartridge-based media to CD-ROM.

Commodore Amiga CD32 (1993 – 1994) 3DO Interactive Multiplayer (1993 – 1996) Pioneer LaserActive LD-ROM (1993 – 1996) Atari Jaguar (1993 – 1996) Sega Saturn CD-ROM (1994 – 1998) Sega Saturn Backup Memory (1994 – 1998)

The Sony PlayStation is launched, and becomes the most successful of the fifth-generation video game consoles. It uses CD-ROM as its main storage media (1994)

Sony PlayStation CD-ROM (1994 – 2006) Sony PlayStation Memory Card (1995 – 2006) Sega 32X (1994 – 1995) Atari Jaguar CD (1995 – 1996) Nintendo Virtual Boy (1995 – 1996) Casio Loopy (1995 – 1997)

Atari leaves the video game console market after disappointing sales of the Atari Jaguar (1996)

Nintendo 64 (1996 – 2003) Nintendo 64 Controller Pak (1996 – 2003) Tiger Electronics Game.com (1997 – 2000)

Philips ceases publishing software for the CD-i (Compact Disc Interactive) format (1998)

SNK Neo Geo Pocket / Pocket Colour (1998 – 2001) Nintendo Game Boy dual-mode cartridge (1998 – 2003) Nintendo Game Boy Color (1998 – 2003) Bandai WonderSwan (1999 – 2000) Nintendo 64DD (Dynamic Drive) (1999 – 2000) Bandai WonderSwan Color / SwanCrystal (2000 – 2003)

Sixth Generation (1998 – 2013)

The sixth-generation (sometimes called the 128-bit era) of video game consoles begins with the launch of the Sega Dreamcast in Japan.

Sega Dreamcast GD-ROM (1998 – 2001) Sega Dreamcast Visual Memory Unit (VMU) (1998 – 2001)

The PlayStation 2, the best-selling video game console of all time, is launched. Arguably, part of its appeal is its ability to play DVD-Video discs (2000)

Sega ceases production of the Dreamcast and exits the video game console market (2001)

Microsoft enters the video game console market in the US with the introduction of the Xbox (2001)

Sony PlayStation 2 CD-ROM (2000 – 2013) Sony PlayStation 2 DVD (2000 – 2013) Sony PlayStation 2 Memory Card (2000 – 2013) Microsoft Xbox (2001 – 2005) Nintendo Game Boy Advance (2001 – 2007) Nintendo GameCube (2001 – 2007) Nintendo GameCube memory card (2001 – 2007) Pokémon mini (2002) Nokia N-Gage card (2003 – 2006) Tapwave Zodiac (2004 – 2005)

Seventh Generation (2005 – 2017)

The seventh-generation of home video game consoles begins with the release of Microsoft’s Xbox 360, although for handhelds the seventh-generation started in late 2004 with the Nintendo DS and Sony PlayStation Portable.

Nintendo DS / DS Lite / DSi (2004 – 2014) Sony PlayStation Portable UMD (2004 – 2014)

Game Wave Family Entertainment System (2005 – 2009)

Microsoft Xbox 360 Hard Drive (2005 – 2010) Microsoft Xbox 360 Memory Unit (2005 – 2010) Microsoft Xbox 360 DVD (2005 – 2016) Gizmondo card (2005 – 2006) VTech V.Flash (2006 – 2007) Sony PlayStation 3 Blu-ray (2006 – 2017) Nintendo Wii Optical Disc (2006 – 2013)

Eighth Generation (2012 – )

Sony PlayStation Vita game card (2011 – 2019) Sony PlayStation Vita memory card (2011 – 2019) Nintendo 3DS (2011 – 2020) Nintendo Wii U Optical Disc (2012 – 2017) Sony PlayStation 4 Blu-ray (2013 – ) Microsoft Xbox One Blu-ray (2013 – ) Nintendo Switch Game Card (2017 – )

Ninth-generation (2020 – )

Microsoft Xbox Series X Ultra HD Blu-ray (2020 – )

Sony PlayStation 5 Ultra HD Blu-ray (2020 – )

Sources / Resources
